perturbation.original_text:
(v) Any Confidential Information, including all copies of same (including that portion of the Confidential Information that consists of analyses, forecasts, studies or other documents prepared by a Party or its advisors, agents, contractors or lenders), shall be returned to the other Party, or at such Party's option destroyed, within five (5) days of (A) a request by a Party at anytime; or (B) the termination of this Agreement in accordance with the terms hereof. Upon the written request of a Party, the other Party shall certify the destruction of such material by written notice to the requesting Party.

(vi) This covenant shall survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement and shall continue in full force and effect for a period of three (3) years thereafter.
perturbation.changed_text:
(v) Any Confidential Information, including all copies of same shall be returned to the other Party, or at such Party's option destroyed, within one (1) day of (A) a request by a Party at anytime; or (B) the termination of this Agreement in accordance with the terms hereof. Upon the written request of a Party, the other Party shall certify the destruction of such material by written notice to the requesting Party.

(vi) This covenant shall survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement and shall continue in full force and effect for a period of one (1) year thereafter.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows five days for the return or destruction of confidential information upon request or termination of the agreement and maintains confidentiality for three years after termination. The modified text reduces the return/destruction period to one day and the confidentiality period to one year. This could be considered unreasonably short, especially concerning trade secrets or sensitive business data, potentially conflicting with trade secret laws that require reasonable measures to protect confidential information for an adequate period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State trade secret laws (e.g., the Uniform Trade Secrets Act, as adopted by many US states) require reasonable measures to protect trade secrets, and a one-year confidentiality period may be deemed insufficient depending on the nature of the information.

perturbation.original_text:
(i) Default. Material nonperformance by the other Party of any provisions set forth in this Agreement which is not cured within thirty (30) days after receipt of notice thereof from the Party not in default; or

(ii) Bankruptcy. The filing by or against the other Party of a petition or application in any proceeding relating to such other Party as debtor under any bankruptcy or insolvency law of any jurisdiction; provided that in the event of an involuntary bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding, such other Party shall have a sixty (60) day period in which to obtain dismissal or withdrawal of such petition or application.
perturbation.changed_text:
(i) Default. Material nonperformance by the other Party of any provisions set forth in this Agreement which is not cured within ten (10) days after receipt of notice thereof from the Party not in default; or

(ii) Bankruptcy. The filing by or against the other Party of a petition or application in any proceeding relating to such other Party as debtor under any bankruptcy or insolvency law of any jurisdiction; provided that in the event of an involuntary bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding, such other Party shall have a thirty (30) day period in which to obtain dismissal or withdrawal of such petition or application.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 30-day cure period for defaults and a 60-day period to dismiss involuntary bankruptcy proceedings. The modified text shortens these periods to 10 and 30 days respectively. A 10-day cure period for significant contractual breaches might be deemed unreasonable, especially for complex issues. Also reducing the time to dismiss an involuntary bankruptcy can also contradict standard business norms.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding reasonable opportunity to cure breaches. Bankruptcy law provisions related to automatic stays and timelines for debtors to respond to involuntary petitions.

perturbation.original_text: All notices and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given upon delivery, if delivered personally or by recognized overnight courier service; if sent by first-class mail, five (5) days after being mailed, return receipt requested and postage prepaid; or if sent by facsimile or e-mail, upon receipt.
perturbation.changed_text: All notices and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given upon delivery, if delivered personally or by recognized overnight courier service; if sent by first-class mail, twenty (20) days after being mailed, return receipt requested and postage prepaid; or if sent by facsimile or e-mail, upon dispatch.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a five-day waiting period for notices sent by first-class mail to be considered duly given. This is a standard business practice. The modified text extends this period to twenty days, which could be viewed as unreasonably long, particularly if there are time-sensitive obligations such as a breach of contract or legal disputes. Additionally, considering an email or fax as delivered upon 'dispatch' instead of 'receipt' can cause some conflicts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring reasonable notice for contractual matters. May conflict with statutes requiring timely notice in certain legal contexts, depending on the specifics of the notice.
